text: The coupling of transcription, translation, and membrane insertion expands the nucleoid into distal parts of the cell.
The spatial orientation of septation has a key role in determining the shape and arrangement of cocci.

If, however, the cell septates in random orientations, or if cells reassociate loosely after septation, they form compact hexagonal arrays similar to the grape clusters portrayed in classical paintings—hence the Greek-derived term staphylococci (staphyle means “bunch of grapes”).
Cell expansion and septation are coordinated with (forming a chain of cells) or at right angles to the previous septation (forming a tetrad).
The facing halves of each cell consist of entirely new cell wall.
If the cell always septates in parallel planes, as in Streptococcus species, cells form chains (Fig. 3.30).
Proteins are folded by chaperones and in some cases secreted at the cell membrane.
If subsequent septation occurs at right angles to the previous division, the cells may form tetrads and even cubical octads called “sarcinae” (singular, sarcina).
The wall material must consist of two separable partitions.
Tetrads are formed by Micrococcus tetragenus, a cause of pulmonary infections (Fig. 3.31).
When the partitions are complete, the two progeny cells peel apart.
Such clusters are found in colonies of Staphylococcus aureus.
Membrane-inserted proteins are translated at the membrane.
envelope at the origin of replication, on domains are supercoiled and bound to DNA-binding proteins.
in a ring all around the cell equator, as new cell wall grows inward.
